I watched the full press conference with Benjamin Rhodes, Deputy National Security Advisor, who is quoted in this article: “We’re actively considering what’s going to be necessary to deal with that threat and we’re not going to be restricted by borders.” He was talking about specific threats to Americans such as the execution of James Foley.

He reiterated over and over that U.S. military intervention is not going to take the fight to ISIL; it is the Iraqi government that is at the front of defeating ISIL in Iraq and must be in order for Iraq to forge and maintain long term stability in their country. And likewise in Syria, the regional governments must take the lead to eliminate ISIL with the U.S. providing support to its partners, the Kurds and Iraqi forces and moderate Syrian insurgents.

Mr. Rhodes reaffirmed the president’s plan to require the Middle East to take responsibility for itself. I hope the president holds firm. Already in the sister article in today’s NYT, “Blamed for Rise of ISIS, Syrian Leader Is Pushed to Escalate Fight,” frightened Syrians who are Assad supporters are quoted as saying that they want the U.S. to take care of ISIL in Syria.

You're joking, right? Banks that keep their loans for years care if the borrower can pay, but banks had been selling mortgages for decades. In the initial part of a loan most of the payments are interest. After that the loan is less profitable, so sell it at a discount and make another. When Wall St started securitizing mortgages the huge demand for more made banks creative in a bad way - bad mortgages turned into gold right away as elements of tranches in AAA securities. This eliminated any concern about repayment and fueled the real estate bubble. And that's just part of it. Banks were also investment banks and, yes, they played with their depositor's money which was guaranteed by the government, making it useful as leverage.

Here's what the banks learned: lobbyists and politicians are a great investment and bigger is better and too big to fail is best. Banks get money interest free from the fed which they lend at higher rates (but they want the loans repaid, hence the new found caution).

As long as there are no alternatives we have to do what the banks want and let them get away with most of what they pull. The only way to make the banks behave is to have an alternative which poses a realistic threat to them.

The lessons the banks should learn is that the government is as trustworthy as any other business partner, and may put the squeeze on them or stab them in the back. But also that at the end of the day, they get to keep most of what they made, nobody goes to jail, and their undeserved reputation for probity and knowing what they are doing will not be seriously attacked. This is not a bad deal for them, but they want more.

There is another important element in both the savings and loans collapse of the 1980's and the mortgage disaster. New entrants came along in both cases to take advantage of the loose, anything goes situation. In the case of S&Ls, people would buy a modest size bank, take deposits from all over the country and then lend the money out in highly questionable ways. The executives of S&Ls also made loans to themselves through corporations they owned or formed, or to close associates. They became giant, personal piggy banks.

Some of the largest losses were in Texas. The economy went into a deep dive, aided by one of the periodic oil busts. I remember flying out of Dallas and seeing hundreds of new, empty houses built on raw land 20 and 30 miles out. Thousands of houses sat abandoned for yrs. Texas "missed out" on some the later mortgage disaster and one factor was a state law against second mortgages.

One key to spinning up the mortgage mess was how quickly the paper (documents) on the loans could be resold for fast profits. The traditional care on qualifications, where those buying houses were made to jump through hoops, went out the window. Write the loan, dispense the money, sell the loan. Then, by securitizing it, the loan passed into a never-never-land where junk loans were turned into triple A bonds. No one did their homework.

Business plays fast and loose whenever it can. When something new comes along to speed up the process, disaster awaits.

Sounds like Public Goods, Common Good etc is a classification system and not a model, or at least what I would call a "indeterminate" model. (One that produces crappy answers).  A model must create a predictive outcome that has utility, that guides you towards the answer when one doesn't know the answer under most reasonable circumstances.  The Professor makes the jump from classification to model when he states "education are not public goods and, in principle, do not warrant public funding".  Knowledge is the greatest public good by far, it meets both requirements.  Take Fractal Geometry created by Mandelbrot at IBM.  Should the government subside IBM? Or the Integrated Circuit by Kilby at TI? I understand they may have patents but that's a very small cost compared to the total economic return generated by that Public Good "knowledge".  I would ask a different question.  Should the government temporarily nationalize the US electric grid system to rationalize the system, similar to what occurred in 1917 to the railroads.  Government should solve problems, at the lowest total cost, especially when private enterprise provides no reasonable solutions.   Such as, rationalizing the making of Doctors?
Apples and Oranges

Pay for training of physicians who will give care to underserved communities and pay for training of physicians who select primary care specialties.  Pay less to train those who will earn the most money.

David, quite simply, you are very very wrong. Manufacturing production in the US is the highest it's ever been--this data is very easy to pull:

http://research.stlouisfed.org/fred2/graph/?g=Iiv

The issue is that manufacturing the US has become extremely high-skilled and capital intensive (especially robotics). This implies many fewer, although better paying, manufacturing jobs in the US. Further, you will not see US manufactured goods at WMT, nor should you expect to. The US manufactures high value added goods-- e.g. aerospace, cars, semiconductors, and large machinery. It does not manufacture cheap plastic / steel crap-- e.g. iPhone assembly. Those are the highly labor intensive (and low value added) manufactures that have been moved offshore. This is what should be expected from even the most basic understanding of Ricardian economics of international trade.
